docs.lead_paragraph: The former governor’s supporters were lukewarm to his candidacy but voted for him in overwhelming numbers.

headline.seo: Big Numbers but Mild Support for Romney in Massachusetts
headline.main: ‘He Should Be All Right,’ Massachusetts Voters Say of Their Ex-Governor
headline.print_headline: ‘He Should Be All Right,’ Massachusetts Voters Say of Their Ex-Governor

docs.abstract: Mitt Romney, as expected, overwhelmingly wins the Massachusetts Republican presidential primary; yet at several polling places around the state, even some voters who supported him were hazy on his accomplishments as governor and lukewarm on his candidacy.
docs.snippet: The former governor’s supporters were lukewarm to his candidacy but voted for him in overwhelming numbers.

byline.contributor: Jess Bidgood contributed reporting from Duxbury and Middleborough, Mass., and Dalia Sussman from New York.

docs.lead_paragraph: Lawmakers proposed the creation of the state’s 12th university and a $1 billion increase for primary and high schools, but the budget also cuts $300 million from universities and colleges.

headline.seo: Florida Higher Education May Face Big Budget Cuts
headline.main: Florida Higher Education May Face Big Budget Cuts
headline.print_headline: Florida Higher Education May Face Big Budget Cuts

docs.abstract: Florida lawmakers propose $70 billion budget that would create the state's 12th university and provide $1 billion increase for primary and high schools, but also cuts $300 million from universities and colleges.
docs.snippet: Lawmakers proposed the creation of the state’s 12th university and a $1 billion increase for primary and high schools, but the budget also cuts $300 million from universities and colleges.

docs.lead_paragraph: The debate in the last few weeks, though, has often involved issues like contraception, or women in combat.

headline.seo: Super Tuesday Exit Polls Show Voters Focused on Economy
headline.main: Voters Said the Economy Was Their Main Issue
headline.print_headline: Whether Struggling or Better Off, Many Voters Said Economy Was Their Main Issue

docs.abstract: Exit polls show voters in Super Tuesday Republican primaries, regardless of the financial condition of their state, considered the economy the top issue influencing their choice.
docs.snippet: The debate in the last few weeks, though, has often involved issues like contraception, or women in combat.

byline.contributor: Robbie Brown and Kim Severson contributed reporting from Atlanta, and Joan Felice Raymond from Willowick, Ohio.

docs.lead_paragraph: The lobbying group for seniors reported an overall rise in the cost of drugs in recent years despite a decrease in the price of generic drugs.

headline.seo: AARP Study Says Price of Popular Drugs Rose 26%
headline.main: AARP Study Says Price of Popular Drugs Rose 26%
headline.print_headline: AARP Study Says Price of Popular Drugs Rose 26%

docs.abstract: Report issued by AARP shows that prices of drugs used most widely by seniors rose by nearly 26 percent from 2005 to 2009; increase occurred even as the price of generic drugs, which account for the majority of prescriptions, has been falling; pharmaceutical industry criticizes report, saying expanded availability of generic drugs has slowed price increases and that the report is flawed.
docs.snippet: The lobbying group for seniors reported an overall rise in the cost of drugs in recent years despite a decrease in the price of generic drugs.

docs.lead_paragraph: When a drug works, patients and insurance companies should pay the full price of the drug. When it doesn’t, they should pay nothing.

headline.seo: Pay Only for Drugs That Help You
headline.main: Pay Only for Drugs That Help You
headline.print_headline: Pay Only for Drugs That Help You

docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Kadmon Corporation founder Samuel D Waksal proposes a system in which health care providers and patients would only pay for drugs if they are effective; holds method would cut costs and create incentives for drug developers; points out a pay-for-response model would also fuel scientific innovation.
docs.snippet: When a drug works, patients and insurance companies should pay the full price of the drug. When it doesn’t, they should pay nothing.

docs.lead_paragraph: The president said that he contacted Sandra Fluke to set an example for his daughters, and he declined to speak on the sincerity of Rush Limbaugh’s apology.

headline.seo: Obama Says He Called Law Student for His Girls
headline.main: Obama’s Call Was a Lesson for His Girls
headline.print_headline: Obama’s Call Was a Lesson For His Girls

docs.abstract: Pres Obama, speaking publicly for the first time about Rush Limbaugh's slur of law student Sandra Fluke on his radio show, says he called her in part to set an example for his daughters; declines to speak on the sincerity of Limbaugh's apology.
docs.snippet: The president said that he contacted Sandra Fluke to set an example for his daughters, and he declined to speak on the sincerity of Rush Limbaugh’s apology.
